title: Over-ambitious Charity Pledge, Funds Now Short
vignette: Someone pledged a large donation to a charity based on a standardized valuation table. Their financial situation has since collapsed, and paying the full amount would be ruinous.

options.text: Allow a reduced payment based on their current ability to pay.
They must eventually pay the full amount they pledged.

title: Redeeming a House Deeded to a Community Trust
vignette: A homeowner transferred the title of his townhouse to a local community land trust during a fundraiser. Months later, he wants to buy it back.

options.text: He may buy it back at market rate, possibly with a small premium to support the trust.
Once donated, a property cannot be returned to the original owner.

title: Late Payment of a Pledged Donation
vignette: Years pass before a donor pays the valuation for a field they pledged to a conservation trust.

options.text: Payment is accepted whenever it comes.
The long delay nullifies the original pledge.

title: Pledge from Demographic Outside Standard Brackets
vignette: A 70-year-old promises a donation based on a 'standardized personal pledge' chart, but the charity's published scale tops out at age 60. Which amount applies?

options.text: Use the highest category (age 60) as the closest equivalent.
Assess a lower amount, acknowledging the person is outside the standard framework.

title: Unauthorized Personal Use of Organizational Assets
vignette: A craftsperson used specialized tools on loan from a museum's workshop for a personal side-job. Is a usage fee owed to the museum?

options.text: They must compensate the museum for the misuse, possibly with a penalty fee.
They should return them with an apology; no fee is necessary for minor, harmless use.

title: Pledging Half the Suggested Amount
vignette: A person vows to give 'half my standard pledge value' to a charity that uses a valuation table.

options.text: A half-payment suffices since that was what was explicitly stated.
Once the standardized pledge system is invoked, the full amount for their category becomes binding.

title: Selling Gifted Land to Fund Current Programs
vignette: Community-owned farmland was originally gifted 'for future generations.' The trust's administrators now propose selling parcels to fund current charitable programs. Is this wise?

options.text: Allowed if proceeds support the trust's core mission.
The land should be held in perpetuity as the donor intended.

title: Pledge for an Infant Before They Are on the Standard Donation Chart
vignette: Parents pledge a monetary 'life value' donation for their infant (three weeks old). The charity's published scale begins at 30 days. What should they pay, if anything?

options.text: There is no fixed value; they can offer a voluntary gift instead.
They should be assigned the lowest valuation category on the chart.

title: Designated Donation Item is Damaged
vignette: An animal designated for a charity auction becomes lame before the event.

options.text: It must be replaced with an equivalent, undamaged donation.
It can be auctioned as-is, with its condition disclosed.

title: Using Donated Assets as Collateral
vignette: A nonprofit leader tries to use studio cameras previously donated to the public media trust as collateral for a short-term loan. Is this allowed?

options.text: Forbidden; the assets belong to the trust and cannot be leveraged for other purposes.
Permitted temporarily if it helps the organization and is repaid quickly.

title: Redeeming Only Half a Lot That Was Gifted
vignette: Half of a two-acre field endowed to a community farm is now needed for a road easement. May the original donor buy back just that strip and leave the rest endowed?

options.text: Allowed by paying the market rate for the redeemed section.
All or nothingâ€”they must buy back the entire field or none of it.

title: Pledge from a Person with Major Financial Obligations
vignette: A person with massive, legally-binding debts makes a large charitable pledge to a foundation.

options.text: Accept the pledge; their charitable intent is separate from their personal debts.
Their creditors must be paid first; the pledge is invalid if it jeopardizes their ability to pay their debts.

title: Donation Made with Hidden Intent to Retract
vignette: A donor signs over company stock but privately plans to find a loophole to rescind the donation before the transfer settles. Does their secret intent invalidate the gift?

options.text: The donation stands based on the formal act; hidden intent is irrelevant.
The hidden intent cancels the pledge.

title: Charity Treasurer Misuses Funds
vignette: A charity's treasurer spends donation money on personal expenses by mistake.

options.text: He must repay the amount with a penalty fee.
If it was a genuine accident, a simple repayment of the principal suffices.

title: Proposal to Equalize Standard Pledge Amounts
vignette: A civic fund uses a legacy table of suggested pledge amounts that has different tiers based on gender. Reformers push for one equal rate for all. Should they adopt the new scale or retain the old one?

options.text: Adopt equal valuations for fairness and to reflect modern values.
Keep the traditional, differentiated amounts out of respect for the fund's history and original bylaws.
